articles.headline: A Moot Effort to Burnish the Reputation of Goldman Sachs
articles.snippet: Since the financial crisis, Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, has striven to build his name back up, but Goldman’s good name has collapsed.
articles.abstract: Since the financial crisis, Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, has striven to build his name back up, but Goldman’s good name has collapsed.
articles.lead_paragraph: I hate to be the bearer of good news for Jamie Dimon, but everything is going to work out O.K.

articles.headline: Technology on the Thames
articles.snippet: The number of technology companies in East London has roughly quadrupled over the last four years, to around 1,400, according to government statistics.
articles.abstract: The number of technology companies in East London has roughly quadrupled over the last four years, to around 1,400, according to government statistics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Parts of this city have the outward signs of a budding high-tech scene. Run-down warehouses have been remodeled into gleaming office spaces. Some greasy diners have been transformed into trendy restaurants. And many wood-paneled pubs have become wine bars.

articles.headline: Jury Finds Bank of America Liable in Mortgage Case
articles.snippet: The jury decision will be seen as a victory for the government in its aggressive effort to hold banks accountable for their role in the housing crisis.
articles.abstract: The jury decision will be seen as a victory for the government in its aggressive effort to hold banks accountable for their role in the housing crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:20 p.m. | Bank of America, one of the nation’s largest banks, was found liable on Wednesday of having sold defective mortgages, a jury decision that will be seen as a victory for the government in its aggressive effort to hold banks accountable for their role in the housing crisis.

articles.headline: Case Explores Rights of Fetus Versus Mother
articles.snippet: A pregnant woman who acknowledged previous painkiller addiction found herself accused of endangering her unborn child and ordered to a drug treatment center.
articles.abstract: A pregnant woman who acknowledged previous painkiller addiction found herself accused of endangering her unborn child and ordered to a drug treatment center.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Wis. — Alicia Beltran cried with fear and disbelief when county sheriffs surrounded her home on July 18 and took her in handcuffs to a holding cell.

articles.headline: Signs of Life in Euro Zone Could Point to Recovery
articles.snippet: A turnaround in Spain comes after an end to recession in Portugal and offers hope to the rest of the periphery, Europe’s so-called misery belt.
articles.abstract: A turnaround in Spain comes after an end to recession in Portugal and offers hope to the rest of the periphery, Europe’s so-called misery belt.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — All the usual caveats still apply, but there is consistent evidence that the worst may be over for Europe’s economy.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: Eye-Catching Wingtips, but They Aren’t for Show
articles.snippet: The technology, called a winglet, attaches to the tip of airplane wings and aims to improve aerodynamics and fuel efficiency.
articles.abstract: The technology, called a winglet, attaches to the tip of airplane wings and aims to improve aerodynamics and fuel efficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: United Airlines is testing the latest innovation in airplane design that may prompt passengers to do a double take. Called a split scimitar, it’s reminiscent of a medieval sword and is a variation on those doodads, known as winglets, that extend up from the tips of wings.

articles.headline: Twitter Illiterate? Mastering the @BC’s
articles.snippet: Only about 18 percent of American Internet users are active on Twitter, so here are some tips if you’re still new to the microblogging service.
articles.abstract: Only about 18 percent of American Internet users are active on Twitter, so here are some tips if you’re still new to the microblogging service.
articles.lead_paragraph: Using Twitter sounds so simple. Type out no more than 140 characters — the maximum allowed in a single tweet — and hit send. That’s all, right?

articles.headline: JPMorgan Faces Possible Penalty in Madoff Case
articles.snippet: Prosecutors are said to be considering possible criminal penalties, suspecting the bank turned a blind eye to Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors are said to be considering possible criminal penalties, suspecting the bank turned a blind eye to Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities are preparing to take action in a criminal investigation of JPMorgan Chase, suspecting that the bank turned a blind eye to Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline:
Health Care
Law Fails to
Lower Prices
for Rural Areas
articles.snippet: More than half of the counties in the 34 states on the federally run health exchange are served by just one or two insurers, and the premiums are high in areas with the least competition.
articles.abstract: More than half of the counties in the 34 states on the federally run health exchange are served by just one or two insurers, and the premiums are high in areas with the least competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: As technical failures bedevil the rollout of President Obama’s health care law, evidence is emerging that one of the program’s loftiest goals — to encourage competition among insurers in an effort to keep costs low — is falling short for many rural Americans.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson, Katie Thomas and Jo Craven McGinty

articles.headline: Dominicans of Haitian Descent Cast Into Legal Limbo by Court
articles.snippet: The nation’s top court has declared that the children of undocumented Haitian migrants — even those born on Dominican soil decades ago — are no longer entitled to citizenship.
articles.abstract: The nation’s top court has declared that the children of undocumented Haitian migrants — even those born on Dominican soil decades ago — are no longer entitled to citizenship.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — For generations, people of Haitian descent have been an inextricable part of life here, often looked at with suspicion and dismay, but largely relied on all the same to clean rooms, build things cheaply and provide the backbreaking labor needed on the country’s vast sugar plantations.

articles.headline: 8 States Teaming Up to Support Electric Cars
articles.snippet: California, New York and six other states said they would work jointly to adopt a range of measures to make it easier to own an electric car.
articles.abstract: California, New York and six other states said they would work jointly to adopt a range of measures to make it easier to own an electric car.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an effort to spur lackluster sales of electric cars, California, New York and six other states said on Thursday that they would work jointly to adopt a range of measures, including encouraging more charging stations and changing building codes, to make it easier to own an electric car.
